description: From Middle English apperen, aperen, borrowed from Old French aparoir (French apparoir, apparaître), from Latin appāreō (“I appear”), from ad (“to”) + pāreō (“I come forth, I become visible”), ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *peh₂-s- (“watch, see”), s-present of *peh₂- (“protect”).

verbs.description: appear (third-person singular simple present appears, present participle appearing, simple past and past participle appeared)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To come or be in sight; to be in view; to become visible.
examples: And God […] said, Let […] the dry land appear.
A great writer appeared at that time.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To stand in presence of some authority, tribunal, or superior person, to answer a charge, plead a cause, etc.; to present oneself as a party or advocate before a court, or as a person to be tried.
examples: We must all appear before the judgment seat.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To become visible to the apprehension of the mind; to be known as a subject of observation or comprehension, or as a thing proved; to be obvious or manifest.
examples: It doth not yet appear what we shall be.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, copulative) To seem; to have a certain semblance; to look.
examples: He appeared quite happy with the result.
[Angelo] is yet a devil / His filth within being cast, he would appear / A pond as deep as hell.
